Award.AwardTitle: MATH: EAGER: Online Collaborative Problem Solving in Remedial College Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a study of the impact of the learning environment on undergraduate students learning problem-solving in remedial pre-calculus mathematics. The study will examine the comparative effectiveness of face-to-face discussion groups and 2 different types of online designs, compared to individual practice. Students will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: three treatment groups that carry out collaborative problem solving using (1) face-to-face discussion, (2) an audio capability with a whiteboard online tool, or (3) an online virtual environment combining audio plus whiteboard plus avatar-based interaction; or a control group of individual problem solving. Currently, pre-calculus instruction is been carried out online in this university using the web-based ALEKS tutorial software, an online interactive learning system that uses an artificial intelligence algorithm to assess and report student mastery of content material. In search of improved student performance, this project is conducting an early in-depth study of the effectiveness of a richer online design for learning problem solving that was recently constructed for management courses, called VirBELA (Virtual Business Education Leadership Assessment). It is a learning platform that offers students the opportunity to work in teams. In mathematics, VirBELA has good potential for facilitating group problem-solving. It provides a whiteboard that allows students to draw diagrams and functions as needed and also provides an audio capability for discussion. It has the added feature of giving students a virtual online embodiment by creating an avatar for each student. There is evidence from other sources that avatars create a richer, more interactive and engaging online collaborative environment that more closely replicates the advantages of in-person communication.

A wide range of data will be collected and assessed, including usage logs of the tutorial learning software, common final exam scores in both pre-calculus and calculus, and individual institutional data. Other outcome variables will include how students perform on the problem solving, how they use the tutorial-based mathematics software before and after problem solving sessions, and whether they persist to the next calculus course, what grades they earn in the following calculus course, and how their attitudes toward STEM study change based on pre- and post-surveys. The study will be repeated in three different quarters.

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study used a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to examine whether incorporating collaborative problem-solving in virtual learning environment influences student course engagement, performance, and attitudes toward STEM and virtual learning, and whether the delivery format of small group problem solving mattered. In addition to the main effects of the problem-solving activities, we also examined whether these effects vary across different subpopulations of students.

The study was conducted in several iterations of an online Pre-Calculus course at University of California, Irvine from September 20, 2015 to August 31, 2017. All the Pre-Calculus courses were taught online through ALEKS (an online interactive learning system that uses an artificial intelligence algorithm to assess and report student mastery of content material) and were offered during summer, fall, and winter quarters, where students study at their own pace and have milestones to meet throughout the 10-week duration of the fall and winter quarters, and 5-week duration in the summer. Students enrolled in the Pre-Calculus course during the study period were required to complete five course assignments throughout the term and students were randomly assigned into four groups: three treatment groups (small group problem solving through face-to-face; small group problem solving through Scribblar; small group problem solving through VirBELA) and one control group (individual problem solving). The face-to-face groups were required to attend the small group problem solving sessions in person. The Scribblar groups instead met and discussed with their group members on Scribblar, which is an interactive whiteboard and audio. The VirBELA groups also met in the virtual environment, but instead through the VirBELA software, which provided whiteboard and enabled virtual embodiment via avatars.

The first two iterations of the study, carried out during fall and winter quarters of the 2015-2016 school year, faced a compliance issue as many students completed problem solving assignments alone even though they were assigned into one of the three treatment conditions that required group work.

Starting in summer 2016, we made a few adjustments to address the compliance issues. First, we made the group assignment only available to the groups either through the platform (for VirBELA or Scribblar) or during group meeting time (for the face-to-face group), thus preventing students from completing and submitting the assignments individually. To ensure that students were able to attend the group-solving activities, we asked students to sign up for a discussion section; we then randomly assigned these discussion sections to one of the four conditions. In the summer, students either enrolled in the course during the first session or the second session, each with only one section available. Each session was randomly assigned either the Scribblar or VirBELA condition since many students lived away from campus and could not meet in-person. During the regular school year, students had to enroll in either one of eight (fall) or one of four (winter) possible discussion sections when they would complete the course assignment. The course assignments were only made available on the platform (in the case of summer) or during the designated section time (in the case of fall and winter).

Additionally, following advice from our advisor, group members rotated to serve as the group leader, who would be responsible for moderating the group discussions and be in charge of turning in the group’s answers to the CPA questions on behalf of the group. These adjustments substantially improved compliance in the later iterations of our study: during Year 2 of our study (2016-2017 academic year), 89% of students completed three out of the five problem solving tasks in their assigned condition.

Based on analyses using data from Year 2, we found that students in sessions that were randomly assigned to the in-person or Scribblar group conditions completed more assignments than the alone condition. Students in the VirBELA group condition completed slightly more assignments than the alone condition, though this finding was not significant.

In terms of course grades, we identified positive, though non-significant, effects for each of the treatment conditions on student grades compared to the alone (control) condition. Yet, further exploration by student characteristics also revealed noticeable heterogeneous impacts by subgroups of students. Specifically, we found that the group-solving activities particularly benefit male students, white students, students from higher-income background, and students with higher-than-average SAT scores, whereas students who were female, Hispanic, low-income or had lower SAT scores benefited little from these group-solving activities.

The survey results echo the patterns observed with course grades: students in all three treatment conditions reported more positive attitudes toward working with groups on math problems than the alone condition. Students in the in-person group felt significantly more belongingness toward the course and classmates than the alone condition. Similar to the differential impacts on grades by sub-groups of students, male students and students with higher SAT scores had more positive changes in attitudes as a result of group-solving activities.
